elements.content: A noninterpenetrated organosulfonate-based metal–organic framework (MOF) with a defective primitive–cubic (pcu) topology was successfully synthesized. The unusual missing linkers, along with the highest permanent porosity (∼43%) in sulfonate-MOFs, offer a versatile platform for the incorporation of alkynophilic Ag­(I) sites. The cyclic carboxylation of alkyne molecules (e.g., propargyl alcohol and propargyl amine) into α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates and oxazolidinones were successfully catalyzed by the use of Ag­(I)-embedded sulfonate-MOF under atmospheric pressure of CO2. In all the three catalytic reactions using CO2 as a C1 feedstock, the highly robust sulfonate-based MOF catalyst exhibit at least three-cycle reusability.
elements.clean_text: A noninterpenetrated organosulfonate-based metal-organic framework (MOF) with a defective primitive-cubic (pcu) topology was successfully synthesized. The unusual missing linkers, along with the highest permanent porosity (~43%) in sulfonate-MOFs, offer a versatile platform for the incorporation of alkynophilic Ag(I) sites. The cyclic carboxylation of alkyne molecules (e.g., propargyl alcohol and propargyl amine) into α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates and oxazolidinones were successfully catalyzed by the use of Ag(I)-embedded sulfonate-MOF under atmospheric pressure of CO2. In all the three catalytic reactions using CO2 as a C1 feedstock, the highly robust sulfonate-based MOF catalyst exhibit at least three-cycle reusability.

elements.content: Carbon dioxide (CO2), the anthropogenically emitted gas, has become a widely recognized issue for global warming and subsequent environmental problems. Transformation of CO2 to high-value chemicals is an emerging strategy to utilize CO2 as a renewable C1 resource, although CO2 is the most thermodynamically stable state in carbon derivatives. The cyclization of unsaturated organic molecules via CO2 is an atom-economical and environmentally benign approach to produce α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates and oxazolidinones, which are the essential building blocks for plastics and antibiotics, respectively. However, precious transition-metal catalyzed processes often are not heterogeneous and/or require harsh conditions (e.g., high temperature and CO2 pressure) to perform the carboxylative cyclization. Thus, it is challenging and imperative to discover highly robust catalysts to achieve the conversion under ambient conditions (ideally at 1 bar and room temperature) in an environmental friendly and recyclable manner.
elements.clean_text: Carbon dioxide (CO2), the anthropogenically emitted gas, has become a widely recognized issue for global warming and subsequent environmental problems. Transformation of CO2 to high-value chemicals is an emerging strategy to utilize CO2 as a renewable C1 resource, although CO2 is the most thermodynamically stable state in carbon derivatives. The cyclization of unsaturated organic molecules via CO2 is an atom-economical and environmentally benign approach to produce α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates and oxazolidinones, which are the essential building blocks for plastics and antibiotics, respectively. However, precious transition-metal catalyzed processes often are not heterogeneous and/or require harsh conditions (e.g., high temperature and CO2 pressure) to perform the carboxylative cyclization. Thus, it is challenging and imperative to discover highly robust catalysts to achieve the conversion under ambient conditions (ideally at 1 bar and room temperature) in an environmental friendly and recyclable manner.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are an emerging class of functionalized solid-state catalysts, because of their site-isolated catalytic sites, well-defined porosity, versatile functionalities, and great reusability. Moreover, MOFs are developed to be one of the most efficient and promising CO2 adsorbents, thus significantly enhancing the local concentration of CO2 near the catalytic sites for its conversion. To date, the vast majority of MOF-based catalysts for organic transformations of CO2 have been largely limited to the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides (or aziridines), while the three-membered epoxide is a very high-energy starting material. Moreover, the co-catalyst (e.g. n-Bu4NBr) plays a significant role in the reaction and performs turnover by itself, thus many mechanistic details must be addressed. An alternate strategy to use CO2 as a C1 feedstock in organic synthesis is the carboxylation of terminal alkyne molecules. The only two successful MOF-related examples are either not completely recyclable or use MOF as a host for encapsulating catalytic species. Very recently, Duan and co-workers reported a Ag­(I)-based MOF catalyzing the carboxylative cyclization of propargyl alcohols with CO2, although in need of elevated temperature and pressure (50 °C, 5 bar).
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are an emerging class of functionalized solid-state catalysts, because of their site-isolated catalytic sites, well-defined porosity, versatile functionalities, and great reusability. Moreover, MOFs are developed to be one of the most efficient and promising CO2 adsorbents, thus significantly enhancing the local concentration of CO2 near the catalytic sites for its conversion. To date, the vast majority of MOF-based catalysts for organic transformations of CO2 have been largely limited to the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides (or aziridines), while the three-membered epoxide is a very high-energy starting material. Moreover, the co-catalyst (e.g. n-Bu4NBr) plays a significant role in the reaction and performs turnover by itself, thus many mechanistic details must be addressed. An alternate strategy to use CO2 as a C1 feedstock in organic synthesis is the carboxylation of terminal alkyne molecules. The only two successful MOF-related examples are either not completely recyclable or use MOF as a host for encapsulating catalytic species. Very recently, Duan and co-workers reported a Ag(I)-based MOF catalyzing the carboxylative cyclization of propargyl alcohols with CO2, although in need of elevated temperature and pressure (50 °C, 5 bar).

elements.content: Reticular engineering of MOF architectures is closely related to the prominent metal-carboxylate secondary building units, which result in the nonpolar porosity of the unfunctionalized carboxylate-based MOFs. In contrast, the versatile metal-sulfonate coordination modes are promising to achieve rich architectures of organosulfonate-based MOFs with high polar porosity and inherent metal/linker vacancies. However, hard metal centers usually prefer the aqua-ligands over sulfonates, thus affording dense zero- or one-dimensional structures. Recently, we employed a mixed-linker strategy to construct three-dimensional (3D) porous organosulfonate-based MOFs possessing a prototypical primitive–cubic (pcu) topology. On the other hand, defect engineering in MOFs is a phenomenal concept where the metal or linker vacancies provide potentially active sites for gas sorption and catalysis.
elements.clean_text: Reticular engineering of MOF architectures is closely related to the prominent metal-carboxylate secondary building units, which result in the nonpolar porosity of the unfunctionalized carboxylate-based MOFs. In contrast, the versatile metal-sulfonate coordination modes are promising to achieve rich architectures of organosulfonate-based MOFs with high polar porosity and inherent metal/linker vacancies. However, hard metal centers usually prefer the aqua-ligands over sulfonates, thus affording dense zero- or one-dimensional structures. Recently, we employed a mixed-linker strategy to construct three-dimensional (3D) porous organosulfonate-based MOFs possessing a prototypical primitive-cubic (pcu) topology. On the other hand, defect engineering in MOFs is a phenomenal concept where the metal or linker vacancies provide potentially active sites for gas sorption and catalysis.

elements.content: Herein, we discover a noninterpenetrated sulfonate-based porous MOF with a prototypical pcu topology. Moreover, the defective, porous topology possesses unusual ligand vacancies in an ordered fashion, affording an array of linker-pendant sulfonate groups for Ag­(I) metalation. The synergistic effect of high CO2 affinity and alkyne activation enables the Ag­(I)-decorated sulfonate-MOF to be an efficient catalyst for cyclization of alkyne and CO2, affording α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates and oxazolidinones with high yields under ambient conditions. Importantly, this is a MOF catalyst to perform all three CO2-based carboxylative cyclization reactions for at least three cycles under atmospheric pressure and room temperature, attributable to its precisely functionalized porosity and high robustness.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we discover a noninterpenetrated sulfonate-based porous MOF with a prototypical pcu topology. Moreover, the defective, porous topology possesses unusual ligand vacancies in an ordered fashion, affording an array of linker-pendant sulfonate groups for Ag(I) metalation. The synergistic effect of high CO2 affinity and alkyne activation enables the Ag(I)-decorated sulfonate-MOF to be an efficient catalyst for cyclization of alkyne and CO2, affording α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates and oxazolidinones with high yields under ambient conditions. Importantly, this is a MOF catalyst to perform all three CO2-based carboxylative cyclization reactions for at least three cycles under atmospheric pressure and room temperature, attributable to its precisely functionalized porosity and high robustness.

elements.content: The multitopic 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramethanesulfonate (1,2,4,5-BTMS) ligand was obtained in high yield (>90%) by the substitution reaction of 1,2,4,5-tetrakis­(bromomethyl)­benzene with sodium sulfite (see in the Supporting Information (ESI)). Hydrothermal reaction of Cu­(NO3)2, 1,2,4,5-BTMS, and 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy) afforded dark-blue block crystals of [Cu­(bpy)2(1,2,4,5-BTMS)0.5(H2O)0.5] n (see in the ESI), which we denote as TMOF-3 (where TMOF is the Tongji MOF). X-ray crystallography reveals TMOF-3 is crystallized in a monoclinic space group of C2/c. The overall structure occupies a prototypical, noninterpenetrated pcu-net topology with an “I0O3” connectivity, using Cheetham et al.’s proposed nomenclature (). The pcu network can be viewed as single Cu2+ atoms connected in three dimensions with the organic struts of bpy and 1,2,4,5-BTMS. Each 1,2,4,5-BTMS ligand has only two para-positioned sulfonate groups forming coordination bonds (RO2S–O···Cu) with Cu2+ nodes, presenting as the pillars for the adjacent (4,4)-connected bricklike [Cu­(bpy)2] n 2n+ layers. The other two sulfonate functional groups are deprotonated and dangling in the cavity of the pcu net (b and c), suggested by the overall charge compensation based on X-ray crystallography as well as Fourier-transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) ( in the ESI). Importantly, 50% of the 1,2,4,5-BTMS ligands are missing in the defective pcu net, and the overall linker vacancies of the total organic linkers in TMOF-3 reach up to 1/6 (16.7%). The presence of the unusual ligand vacancies is probably due to the steric effect of the tetratopic 1,2,4,5-BTMS, as well as the competing coordinating tendencies between aqua-ligands and sulfonates. The coordination spheres of the defective Cu2+ centers are completed by two weakly bound water molecules in the axial positions with a long contact distance of 2.45 Å (see ).
elements.clean_text: The multitopic 1,2,4,5-benzenetetramethanesulfonate (1,2,4,5-BTMS) ligand was obtained in high yield (>90%) by the substitution reaction of 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(bromomethyl)benzene with sodium sulfite (see  in the Supporting Information (ESI)). Hydrothermal reaction of Cu(NO3)2, 1,2,4,5-BTMS, and 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) afforded dark-blue block crystals of [Cu(bpy)2(1,2,4,5-BTMS)0.5(H2O)0.5] n  (see  in the ESI), which we denote as TMOF-3 (where TMOF is the Tongji MOF). X-ray crystallography reveals TMOF-3 is crystallized in a monoclinic space group of C2/c. The overall structure occupies a prototypical, noninterpenetrated pcu-net topology with an "I0O3" connectivity, using Cheetham et al.'s proposed nomenclature (). The pcu network can be viewed as single Cu2+ atoms connected in three dimensions with the organic struts of bpy and 1,2,4,5-BTMS. Each 1,2,4,5-BTMS ligand has only two para-positioned sulfonate groups forming coordination bonds (RO2S-O⋅⋅⋅Cu) with Cu2+ nodes, presenting as the pillars for the adjacent (4,4)-connected bricklike [Cu(bpy)2] n  2n+ layers. The other two sulfonate functional groups are deprotonated and dangling in the cavity of the pcu net (b and c), suggested by the overall charge compensation based on X-ray crystallography as well as Fourier-transformed infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) ( in the ESI). Importantly, 50% of the 1,2,4,5-BTMS ligands are missing in the defective pcu net, and the overall linker vacancies of the total organic linkers in TMOF-3 reach up to 1/6 (16.7%). The presence of the unusual ligand vacancies is probably due to the steric effect of the tetratopic 1,2,4,5-BTMS, as well as the competing coordinating tendencies between aqua-ligands and sulfonates. The coordination spheres of the defective Cu2+ centers are completed by two weakly bound water molecules in the axial positions with a long contact distance of 2.45 Å (see ).

elements.content: (a) Scheme of TMOF-3 synthesis; (b) crystallographic view of TMOF-3 along the b-axis and 4,4′-bipyridines are simplified as rods for clarity; (c) topological view of TMOF-3 with the uncoordinated sulfonate groups highlighted (Cu = green, O = red, S = yellow).

elements.content: Coordination environment of the Cu­(II) centers in TMOF-3 (Cu = green, O = red, S = yellow, C = gray, N = blue).
elements.clean_text: 2  Coordination environment of the Cu(II) centers in TMOF-3 (Cu = green, O = red, S = yellow, C = gray, N = blue).

elements.content: Overall, TMOF-3 is a noninterpenetrated organosulfonate-based MOF with a pcu-type topology, and it possesses the highest void space (42.5% by PLATON calculations) among MOFs containing an organosulfonate linker. Moreover, its high yield and phase purity are evidenced by experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), which matches well with theoretical pattern simulated from the crystallographic studies (see ). Despite occupying a defective pcu network, TMOF-3 demonstrates a high chemical robustness over a wide pH range from 3 to 10, as well as the aqueous condition. After incubating the isolated TMOF-3 crystals in water, diluted HCl solution (pH 3) and diluted NaOH solution (pH 10) for 24 h, no significant loss of crystallinity was observed in PXRD patterns, as well as Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas (see , as well as in the Supporting Information). The water-stable nature of TMOF-3 is probably ascribed to the Cu­(II) centers occupying an energetically stable Jahn–Teller distorted octahedral geometry and, thus, is less susceptible to hydrolysis and outperforming the vast majority of carboxylate-based MOFs with a pcu topology.
elements.clean_text: Overall, TMOF-3 is a noninterpenetrated organosulfonate-based MOF with a pcu-type topology, and it possesses the highest void space (42.5% by PLATON calculations) among MOFs containing an organosulfonate linker. Moreover, its high yield and phase purity are evidenced by experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), which matches well with theoretical pattern simulated from the crystallographic studies (see ). Despite occupying a defective pcu network, TMOF-3 demonstrates a high chemical robustness over a wide pH range from 3 to 10, as well as the aqueous condition. After incubating the isolated TMOF-3 crystals in water, diluted HCl solution (pH 3) and diluted NaOH solution (pH 10) for 24 h, no significant loss of crystallinity was observed in PXRD patterns, as well as Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas (see , as well as  in the Supporting Information). The water-stable nature of TMOF-3 is probably ascribed to the Cu(II) centers occupying an energetically stable Jahn-Teller distorted octahedral geometry and, thus, is less susceptible to hydrolysis and outperforming the vast majority of carboxylate-based MOFs with a pcu topology.

elements.content: PXRD patterns of TMOF-3/TMOF-3-Ag before and after chemical treatment.
elements.clean_text: 3  PXRD patterns of TMOF-3/TMOF-3-Ag before and after chemical treatment.

elements.content: Successful activation of TMOF-3 was performed by incubation of the solids in fresh methanol solution, followed by high-vacuum activation at room temperature for overnight. The nature of permanent porosity and the retention of pcu topology were demonstrated by the agreement of the PXRD between the activated sample and simulated data from single-crystal data (see in the ESI). The activated TMOF-3 exhibited a BET surface area of 870 m2/g with a reversible type I sorption isotherm measured by N2 adsorption at 77 K, demonstrating its microporous nature (see a, as well as in the ESI). Since the vast array of strongly polar sulfonate groups (both coordinated and dangling) would have a high affinity toward CO2, TMOF-3 showed a high CO2 uptake of 102 cm3/g (20.0 wt %) at 273 K and 74 cm3/g (14.5 wt %) at 298 K under 1 bar. To the best of our knowledge, these numbers are not only the highest in all of the organosulfonate-based MOFs, but also are among the best performances in the low-pressure CO2 adsorption capacities for functionalized carboxylate-based MOFs. The zero-coverage isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of TMOF-3 was calculated to be 29.2 kJ/mol, further confirming the strong affinity of TMOF-3 to CO2. Indeed, TMOF-3 demonstrated a rather steep increase at low pressure in H2 sorption isotherms (77 and 87 K) and a Q st value of 9.0 kJ/mol (see in the ESI), which is probably due to the coordinatively unsaturated Cu­(II) sites residing in activated TMOF-3.

The activated TMOF-3 exhibited a BET surface area of 870 m2/g with a reversible type I sorption isotherm measured by N2 adsorption at 77 K, demonstrating its microporous nature (see a, as well as  in the ESI). Since the vast array of strongly polar sulfonate groups (both coordinated and dangling) would have a high affinity toward CO2, TMOF-3 showed a high CO2 uptake of 102 cm3/g (20.0 wt %) at 273 K and 74 cm3/g (14.5 wt %) at 298 K under 1 bar. To the best of our knowledge, these numbers are not only the highest in all of the organosulfonate-based MOFs, but also are among the best performances in the low-pressure CO2 adsorption capacities for functionalized carboxylate-based MOFs. The zero-coverage isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of TMOF-3 was calculated to be 29.2 kJ/mol, further confirming the strong affinity of TMOF-3 to CO2. Indeed, TMOF-3 demonstrated a rather steep increase at low pressure in H2 sorption isotherms (77 and 87 K) and a Q st value of 9.0 kJ/mol (see  in the ESI), which is probably due to the coordinatively unsaturated Cu(II) sites residing in activated TMOF-3.

elements.content: (a) N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at 77 K, TMOF-3 black, TMOF-3-Ag blue; (b) CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of TMOF-3, 273 K (black) and 298 K (blue symbols).
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K, TMOF-3 black, TMOF-3-Ag blue; (b) CO2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of TMOF-3, 273 K (black) and  298 K (blue symbols).

elements.content: The high porosity and the immobilized, linker-pendant sulfonate groups on TMOF-3 provide an excellent platform to introduce a second metal center, such as alkynophilic Ag­(I) sites. Successful Ag­(I) metalation was performed by incubating ∼120 mg of activated sample of TMOF-3 in 10 mL of AgNO3 aqueous solution (10 mmol/L) and fixed onto a shaker (IKA KS 3000) with a shaking rate of 100 cpm for 1 h, affording the resulting TMOF-3-Ag (a). Inductively coupled plasma–optical emission spectra (ICP-OES) revealed an atomic ratio of 1:(5.8 ± 0.3) (Ag:Cu) in the Ag­(I)-decorated TMOF-3, confirming that ∼17% of the free sulfonate sites were metalated. X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) indicated a characteristic binding energy of Ag­(I) (368.1 and 374.2 eV) in TMOF-3-Ag, which is comparable with CH3SO3Ag (368.3 and 374.3 eV) ( in the ESI). Moreover, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images exhibited no deposition of Ag nanoparticles on the crystal surface ( in the ESI). ICP-OES of the Ag­(I)-metalation supernatant showed no leaching of Cu from TMOF-3, excluding the possibility of a cation exchange process. In addition, the nearest distance between two dangling sulfonate groups is ∼6.6 Å, which is obviously too long to chelate a single Ag­(I) ion. These experiments suggest the formation of AgO3S-R moieties in TMOF-3-Ag. The high crystallinity of TMOF-3 was well-retained throughout the metalation, as evidenced by PXRD and the resulting dark-blue crystals (). Indeed, a high water stability and an expected decrease in BET surface area (627 m2/g) were observed for TMOF-3-Ag ( and a).

Moreover, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images exhibited no deposition of Ag nanoparticles on the crystal surface ( in the ESI). Indeed, a high water stability and an expected decrease in BET surface area (627 m2/g) were observed for TMOF-3-Ag ( and a).

elements.content: (a) Scheme representation of the Ag­(I) metalation for TMOF-3, ligands are simplified as rods for clarity; (b) ethane and acetylene sorption of TMOF-3-Ag; (c) FTIR spectra of 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol (a) (black), TMOF-3 before (blue) and after (red) treating with a, and TMOF-3-Ag before (cyan) and after (magenta) treatment with a.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Scheme representation of the Ag(I) metalation for TMOF-3, ligands are simplified as rods for clarity; (b) ethane and acetylene sorption of TMOF-3-Ag; (c) FTIR spectra of 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol (a) (black), TMOF-3 before (blue) and after (red) treating with a, and TMOF-3-Ag before (cyan) and after (magenta) treatment with a.

elements.content: Since silver complexes are known to have both σ-complexation and π-complexation properties with terminal alkynes, we used the gas adsorption and FTIR to examine the activation of CC bonds by TMOF-3-Ag. The low-pressure acetylene sorption isotherms of TMOF-3-Ag show the high acetylene uptake capacity of 103 cm3/g (12.0 wt %) at 273 K and 75 cm3/g (8.7 wt %) at 298 K, substantially surpassing its ethane uptake capacity under the identical condition (b). Moreover, the Q st of acetylene for TMOF-3-Ag is calculated to be 34.2 kJ/mol, which is significantly higher than that of TMOF-3 (before Ag decoration), as well as some reported high acetylene-uptake MOFs with open metal sites (see in the ESI). In order to further confirm the complexation and activation of alkyne-containing molecules via Ag­(I) sites residing in TMOF-3-Ag, we employed FTIR to characterize both MOFs (before and after Ag­(I) decoration) that are treated with 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol (a). The propargyl alcohol substrate is chosen because it being presenting as the precursor for chemical CO2 fixation that will be discussed later. After extensive washing with fresh ethanol, the new and distinct peaks appear at 2111 and 3295 cm–1 for both MOFs that are characteristic of CC stretching and ≡C–H stretching, respectively (see c, as well as in the ESI). These results confirm the successful inclusion of the propargyl alcohol molecules inside the porosity of TMOF-3 and TMOF-3-Ag. More importantly, the obvious blue-shifted bands at 2162 and 3326 cm–1 were observed in propargyl alcohol-treated TMOF-3-Ag (see c and ), clearly suggesting the complexation and activation of the terminal alkyne moieties within the pores of TMOF-3-Ag.

Moreover, the Q st of acetylene for TMOF-3-Ag is calculated to be 34.2 kJ/mol, which is significantly higher than that of TMOF-3 (before Ag decoration), as well as some reported high acetylene-uptake MOFs with open metal sites (see  in the ESI). In order to further confirm the complexation and activation of alkyne-containing molecules via Ag(I) sites residing in TMOF-3-Ag, we employed FTIR to characterize both MOFs (before and after Ag(I) decoration) that are treated with 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol (a). The propargyl alcohol substrate is chosen because it being presenting as the precursor for chemical CO2 fixation that will be discussed later. After extensive washing with fresh ethanol, the new and distinct peaks appear at 2111 and 3295 cm-1 for both MOFs that are characteristic of CC stretching and ≡C-H stretching, respectively (see c, as well as  in the ESI). These results confirm the successful inclusion of the propargyl alcohol molecules inside the porosity of TMOF-3 and TMOF-3-Ag. More importantly, the obvious blue-shifted bands at 2162 and 3326 cm-1 were observed in propargyl alcohol-treated TMOF-3-Ag (see c and ), clearly suggesting the complexation and activation of the terminal alkyne moieties within the pores of TMOF-3-Ag.

elements.content: Given the synergistic nature of the high CO2 affinity and alkyne activation from TMOF-3-Ag, we sought to investigate its catalytic activity in carboxylative cyclization of propargyl alcohol with CO2. The cyclization of unsaturated 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol to produce α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates was carried out under very mild conditions (1 atm CO2 and room temperature), and 1,8-diazabicyclo-[5.4.0]­underc-7-ene (DBU) was proven to be an efficient base for this type of carboxylation reaction. Using TMOF-3-Ag (10 mol % in Ag), the quantitative yield of the targeted α-alkylidene cyclic carbonate product was achieved in 6 h. Meanwhile, TMOF-3 before Ag decoration gave no conversion, evidencing the catalytically active Ag­(I) sites. Despite the fact that the homogeneous AgNO3 completed the reaction under the same conditions, our MOF catalyst exhibits excellent recyclability without an obvious decrease in both yields and kinetics over three catalytic cycles (see in the ESI). The crystalline TMOF-3-Ag could be simply recovered by filtration, washed with ethanol, dried under vacuum, and then directly used for additional cycles. The post-catalysis TMOF-3-Ag exhibited no change in oxidation state and coordination environment of the Ag­(I) catalytic sites, despite the decreased crystallinity, evidenced by XPS, TEM, and PXRD (see , respectively, in the ESI). The heterogeneous nature of TMOF-3-Ag was further confirmed by a hot filtration of the catalyst after the first hour of the reaction, which resulted in negligible additional yield up to 5 h after filtration (see in the ESI). Moreover, no leaching of metal species was detected by ICP-OES, showing the presence of merely 0.3 ppm Ag and 0.1 ppm of Cu in the reaction solution. These experiments suggest that TMOF-3-Ag is a true heterogeneous catalyst.

The crystalline TMOF-3-Ag could be simply recovered by filtration, washed with ethanol, dried under vacuum, and then directly used for additional cycles. The post-catalysis TMOF-3-Ag exhibited no change in oxidation state and coordination environment of the Ag(I) catalytic sites, despite the decreased crystallinity, evidenced by XPS, TEM, and PXRD (see , respectively, in the ESI). The heterogeneous nature of TMOF-3-Ag was further confirmed by a hot filtration of the catalyst after the first hour of the reaction, which resulted in negligible additional yield up to 5 h after filtration (see  in the ESI). Moreover, no leaching of metal species was detected by ICP-OES, showing the presence of merely 0.3 ppm Ag and 0.1 ppm of Cu in the reaction solution. These experiments suggest that TMOF-3-Ag is a true heterogeneous catalyst.

elements.content: Importantly, this is one of the few examples to catalyze the carboxylative cyclization of propargyl alcohol under ambient conditions (1 atm CO2, room temperature) using MOF materials. To note, the high activity of our TMOF-3-Ag gives quantitative yields using merely 10 mol % co-catalyst (DBU), while other homogeneous or heterogeneous catalyst often require a stoichiometric amount of the toxic/costly base or high CO2 pressure (see in the ESI). Seven propargyl alcohols were used as substrates to synthesize the α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates (). Among them, the majority of the unsaturated molecules gave an almost-quantitative yield. Meanwhile, the internal propargyl alcohol affords the corresponding carbonate in 25(5)% yield, probably due to its steric hindrance to diffuse into the MOF porosity, as well as the insufficient π-activation of Ag­(I) sites toward internal alkyne moieties (see ).
elements.clean_text: Importantly, this is one of the few examples to catalyze the carboxylative cyclization of propargyl alcohol under ambient conditions (1 atm CO2, room temperature) using MOF materials. To note, the high activity of our TMOF-3-Ag gives quantitative yields using merely 10 mol% co-catalyst (DBU), while other homogeneous or heterogeneous catalyst often require a stoichiometric amount of the toxic/costly base or high CO2 pressure (see  in the ESI). Seven propargyl alcohols were used as substrates to synthesize the α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates (). Among them, the majority of the unsaturated molecules gave an almost-quantitative yield. Meanwhile, the internal propargyl alcohol affords the corresponding carbonate in 25(5)% yield, probably due to its steric hindrance to diffuse into the MOF porosity, as well as the insufficient π-activation of Ag(I) sites toward internal alkyne moieties (see ).

elements.content:
Carboxylic Cyclization of Propargylic Alcohol with CO<sub>2</sub> <xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref>

Reaction conditions: 0.2 mmol propargylic alcohol, 10 mol % TMOF-3-Ag (based on Ag), along with 0.1 equiv DBU, 2 mL DMF, 0.1 MPa CO2 atmosphere, room temperature, 6 h. b Yields determined by 1H NMR, as an average value of three runs (error in parentheses).

The high catalytic activity of TMOF-3-Ag toward the carboxylic cyclization of propargylic alcohols is largely ascribed to the fast mass transport from the high surface area as well as the highly robust nature of the pcu topology. In contrast, the catalytic activity of the heterogeneous Ag­(I) salts strongly interferes with the low accessibility of the metal sites and the limited reaction rate by mass transport. The control reaction between 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol with CO2 catalyzed by a series of Ag­(I) salts afforded rather low yields of the targeted products, as expected (see ).
elements.clean_text: The high catalytic activity of TMOF-3-Ag toward the carboxylic cyclization of propargylic alcohols is largely ascribed to the fast mass transport from the high surface area as well as the highly robust nature of the pcu topology. In contrast, the catalytic activity of the heterogeneous Ag(I) salts strongly interferes with the low accessibility of the metal sites and the limited reaction rate by mass transport. The control reaction between 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol with CO2 catalyzed by a series of Ag(I) salts afforded rather low yields of the targeted products, as expected (see ).

elements.content:
Carboxylic Cyclization of 2-Methyl-3-butyn-2-ol with CO<sub>2</sub> Using Heterogeneous Ag­(I)-Based Catalysts<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t2fn1"></xref> catalyst time (h) yield (%) 1 AgCl 6 9(2) 2 AgBr 6 29(3) 3 AgI 6 26(2) 4 Ag2CO3 6 8(2) 5 Ag2SO4 6 46(3) 6 Ag2S 6 <2 7 TMOF-3 6 0 8 TMOF-3-Ag 6 >99

Reaction conditions: 0.2 mmol 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol, 10 mol % catalyst along with 0.1 eq. DBU, 2 mL DMF, 0.1 MPa CO2 atmosphere, room temperature;

Yields determined by 1H NMR, as an average value of three runs (error in parentheses).

Since oxazolidinones are an important building block for antibiotics, we employed a three-component reaction between propargyl alcohol, CO2 and primary amine to afford the corresponding carbamates (). The atom-economic synthetic strategy catalyzed by a heterogeneous MOF-based catalyst may achieve the completely “green” chemistry process. Importantly, the transformation between a, CO2, and n-propylamine was performed to reach almost quantitative yield with the catalyst of TMOF-3-Ag under extremely mild conditions (1 atm CO2 and 50 °C) after 12 h (see in the ESI). To the best of our knowledge, this is a rare example to achieve this three-component catalytic process at atmospheric CO2 pressure. Notably, TMOF-3-Ag can be easily recovered after the reaction, and then directly used for additional cycles with yields of >90% (). Moreover, six oxazolidinones were obtained successfully, using different propargyl alcohol and primary amines substrates, which likely involves the mechanism of tandem aminolysis of α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates, followed by intramolecular cyclization (see in the ESI).
elements.clean_text: Since oxazolidinones are an important building block for antibiotics, we employed a three-component reaction between propargyl alcohol, CO2 and primary amine to afford the corresponding carbamates (). The atom-economic synthetic strategy catalyzed by a heterogeneous MOF-based catalyst may achieve the completely "green" chemistry process. Importantly, the transformation between a, CO2, and n-propylamine was performed to reach almost quantitative yield with the catalyst of TMOF-3-Ag under extremely mild conditions (1 atm CO2 and 50 °C) after 12 h (see  in the ESI). To the best of our knowledge, this is a rare example to achieve this three-component catalytic process at atmospheric CO2 pressure. Notably, TMOF-3-Ag can be easily recovered after the reaction, and then directly used for additional cycles with yields of >90% (). Moreover, six oxazolidinones were obtained successfully, using different propargyl alcohol and primary amines substrates, which likely involves the mechanism of tandem aminolysis of α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates, followed by intramolecular cyclization (see  in the ESI).

elements.content:
Three-Component Carboxylic Cyclization of Propargyl Alcohol, CO<sub>2</sub>, and Primary Amine<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t3fn1"></xref>

Reaction conditions: 0.2 mmol propargylic alcohol, 0.2 mmol primary amine, certain amount of catalyst (based on Ag), 10 mol % Ph3P, 2 mL DMSO, 0.1 MPa CO2 atmosphere, 50 °C. b Yields determined by 1H NMR, as an average value of three runs (error in parentheses). c Equal mol % of MOF as entry 1.

Following the above three-component catalysis results, we further establish a catalytic protocol to afford oxazolidinones between propargyl amine and CO2. Five different propargyl amines were synthesized, according to the literature, and the cyclic carboxylation with CO2 afforded the targeted carbamate product smoothly with high yields in the presence of 10 mol % DBU and 10 mol % TMOF-3-Ag under 1 atm CO2 (see , as well as in the ESI). Control experiments of TMOF-3 and AgNO3 revealed that embedded Ag­(I) are the true active sites, which undergo the mechanism that the silver-coordinated propargyl amine reacts with CO2-trapped DBU to afford the product via CO2 transfer (see in the ESI). Again, the recyclability experiments were performed using the same batch of 10 mol % TMOF-3-Ag over three cycles without a decrease in yield of the targeted oxazolidinone (see in the ESI).
elements.clean_text: Following the above three-component catalysis results, we further establish a catalytic protocol to afford oxazolidinones between propargyl amine and CO2. Five different propargyl amines were synthesized, according to the literature, and the cyclic carboxylation with CO2 afforded the targeted carbamate product smoothly with high yields in the presence of 10 mol% DBU and 10 mol% TMOF-3-Ag under 1 atm CO2 (see , as well as  in the ESI). Control experiments of TMOF-3 and AgNO3 revealed that embedded Ag(I) are the true active sites, which undergo the mechanism that the silver-coordinated propargyl amine reacts with CO2-trapped DBU to afford the product via CO2 transfer (see  in the ESI). Again, the recyclability experiments were performed using the same batch of 10 mol% TMOF-3-Ag over three cycles without a decrease in yield of the targeted oxazolidinone (see  in the ESI).

elements.content:
Carboxylic Cyclization of Propargyl Amine with CO<sub>2</sub> <xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t4fn1"></xref>

Reaction conditions: 0.2 mmol propargyl amine, 0.1 equiv TMOF-3-Ag (based on Ag) along with 0.1 equiv DBU, 2 mL DMF, 0.1 MPa CO2 atmosphere, room temperature, 6 h. b Yields determined by 1H NMR, as an average value of three runs (error in parentheses). c PMB = p-methoxybenzyl.

In conclusion, we synthesized a noninterpenetrated pcu-type sulfonate-based MOF, and the unusual linker-defective nature allows for the subsequent incorporation of Ag­(I) active sites. The chemically robust TMOF-3-Ag­(I) occupies both the high CO2 affinity from the sulfonate functionality and the alkyne activation nature from the embedded Ag­(I) sites, providing an excellent platform for cyclic carboxylation of alkyne molecules and CO2. The catalysis presented here achieves efficient and recyclable cyclic carboxylation of terminal alkyne substrates and CO2 under very mild conditions (1 atm CO2 and low temperature) using MOF catalysts. This work reveals the potential applications of inherently high-polarity pore surfaces in functionalized and permanently porous sulfonate-based MOFs for CO2 capture and sequestration technologies.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we synthesized a noninterpenetrated pcu-type sulfonate-based MOF, and the unusual linker-defective nature allows for the subsequent incorporation of Ag(I) active sites. The chemically robust TMOF-3-Ag(I) occupies both the high CO2 affinity from the sulfonate functionality and the alkyne activation nature from the embedded Ag(I) sites, providing an excellent platform for cyclic carboxylation of alkyne molecules and CO2. The catalysis presented here achieves efficient and recyclable cyclic carboxylation of terminal alkyne substrates and CO2 under very mild conditions (1 atm CO2 and low temperature) using MOF catalysts. This work reveals the potential applications of inherently high-polarity pore surfaces in functionalized and permanently porous sulfonate-based MOFs for CO2 capture and sequestration technologies.

cln_elements.clean_text: Since oxazolidinones are an important building block for antibiotics, we employed a three-component reaction between propargyl alcohol, CO2 and primary amine to afford the corresponding carbamates (). The atom-economic synthetic strategy catalyzed by a heterogeneous MOF-based catalyst may achieve the completely "green" chemistry process. Importantly, the transformation between a, CO2, and n-propylamine was performed to reach almost quantitative yield with the catalyst of TMOF-3-Ag under extremely mild conditions (1 atm CO2 and 50 °C) after 12 h (see  in the ESI). To the best of our knowledge, this is a rare example to achieve this three-component catalytic process at atmospheric CO2 pressure. Notably, TMOF-3-Ag can be easily recovered after the reaction, and then directly used for additional cycles with yields of >90% (). Moreover, six oxazolidinones were obtained successfully, using different propargyl alcohol and primary amines substrates, which likely involves the mechanism of tandem aminolysis of α-alkylidene cyclic carbonates, followed by intramolecular cyclization (see  in the ESI).

cln_elements.content:
Successful activation of TMOF-3 was performed by incubation of the solids in fresh methanol solution, followed by high-vacuum activation at room temperature for overnight. The nature of permanent porosity and the retention of pcu topology were demonstrated by the agreement of the PXRD between the activated sample and simulated data from single-crystal data (see in the ESI). The activated TMOF-3 exhibited a BET surface area of 870 m2/g with a reversible type I sorption isotherm measured by N2 adsorption at 77 K, demonstrating its microporous nature (see a, as well as in the ESI). Since the vast array of strongly polar sulfonate groups (both coordinated and dangling) would have a high affinity toward CO2, TMOF-3 showed a high CO2 uptake of 102 cm3/g (20.0 wt %) at 273 K and 74 cm3/g (14.5 wt %) at 298 K under 1 bar. To the best of our knowledge, these numbers are not only the highest in all of the organosulfonate-based MOFs, but also are among the best performances in the low-pressure CO2 adsorption capacities for functionalized carboxylate-based MOFs. The zero-coverage isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of TMOF-3 was calculated to be 29.2 kJ/mol, further confirming the strong affinity of TMOF-3 to CO2. Indeed, TMOF-3 demonstrated a rather steep increase at low pressure in H2 sorption isotherms (77 and 87 K) and a Q st value of 9.0 kJ/mol (see in the ESI), which is probably due to the coordinatively unsaturated Cu­(II) sites residing in activated TMOF-3.

Since silver complexes are known to have both σ-complexation and π-complexation properties with terminal alkynes, we used the gas adsorption and FTIR to examine the activation of CC bonds by TMOF-3-Ag. The low-pressure acetylene sorption isotherms of TMOF-3-Ag show the high acetylene uptake capacity of 103 cm3/g (12.0 wt %) at 273 K and 75 cm3/g (8.7 wt %) at 298 K, substantially surpassing its ethane uptake capacity under the identical condition (b). Moreover, the Q st of acetylene for TMOF-3-Ag is calculated to be 34.2 kJ/mol, which is significantly higher than that of TMOF-3 (before Ag decoration), as well as some reported high acetylene-uptake MOFs with open metal sites (see in the ESI). In order to further confirm the complexation and activation of alkyne-containing molecules via Ag­(I) sites residing in TMOF-3-Ag, we employed FTIR to characterize both MOFs (before and after Ag­(I) decoration) that are treated with 2-methyl-3-butyn-2-ol (a). The propargyl alcohol substrate is chosen because it being presenting as the precursor for chemical CO2 fixation that will be discussed later. After extensive washing with fresh ethanol, the new and distinct peaks appear at 2111 and 3295 cm–1 for both MOFs that are characteristic of CC stretching and ≡C–H stretching, respectively (see c, as well as in the ESI). These results confirm the successful inclusion of the propargyl alcohol molecules inside the porosity of TMOF-3 and TMOF-3-Ag. More importantly, the obvious blue-shifted bands at 2162 and 3326 cm–1 were observed in propargyl alcohol-treated TMOF-3-Ag (see c and ), clearly suggesting the complexation and activation of the terminal alkyne moieties within the pores of TMOF-3-Ag.

The zero-coverage isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) of TMOF-3 was calculated to be 29.2 kJ/mol, further confirming the strong affinity of TMOF-3 to CO2. Since silver complexes are known to have both σ-complexation and π-complexation properties with terminal alkynes, we used the gas adsorption and FTIR to examine the activation of CC bonds by TMOF-3-Ag. The low-pressure acetylene sorption isotherms of TMOF-3-Ag show the high acetylene uptake capacity of 103 cm3/g (12.0 wt%) at 273 K and 75 cm3/g (8.7 wt %) at 298 K, substantially surpassing its ethane uptake capacity under the identical condition (b). More importantly, the obvious blue-shifted bands at 2162 and 3326 cm-1 were observed in propargyl alcohol-treated TMOF-3-Ag (see c and ), clearly suggesting the complexation and activation of the terminal alkyne moieties within the pores of TMOF-3-Ag.

metadata.title:
Unusual Missing Linkers in an Organosulfonate-Based Primitive–Cubic
(pcu)-Type Metal–Organic Framework for CO2 Capture
and Conversion under Ambient Conditions
